example.name: ETCS Train Control [simple]
example.description: Essentials of the ETCS train control protocol.This example proves that a train never leaves its movement authority (MA=m) and, thus, cannot crash into other trains. Please note, that this is the simplest possible version of the safety requirement for the ETCS. The verification of the ETCS system itself requires a much more advanced model. Proves equation (2.19)

example.name: ETCS Train Control [simple nondet]
example.description: Essentials of the ETCS train control protocol.This example proves that a train never leaves its movement authority (MA=m) and, thus, cannot crash into other trains. Please note, that this is the simplest possible version of the safety requirement for the ETCS. The verification of the ETCS system itself requires a much more advanced model.

example.name: ETCS Train Control [controllability]
example.description: Proves safety of the ETCS train control protocol case study. This example proves that the train is always controllable safely by some control choice. Proves Proposition 7.1

example.name: ETCS Train Control [safety]
example.description: Proves safety of the ETCS train control protocol case study. This example proves that a train never leaves its movement authority (MA=m) and, thus, cannot crash into other trains. Proves Proposition 7.5

example.name: ETCS Train Control [simpler liveness]
example.description: Proves safety of a slightly simplified ETCS train control protocol case study. This example proves that the train can move beyond every position on the track by just a single choice of movement authority. Proves Proposition 7.6

example.name: ETCS Train Control [liveness]
example.description: Proves safety of the ETCS train control protocol case study. This example proves that the train can move beyond every position on the track. Proves Proposition 7.6

example.name: ETCS Train Control [reactivity]
example.description: Proves safety of the ETCS train control protocol case study. This example proves that the train can react to situation changes. Proves Proposition 7.4

example.name: ETCS Train Disturbance [controllability]
example.description: Proves safety of the ETCS train control protocol case study despite disturbance in the physical dynamics. This example proves that the train is always controllable safely by some control choice, despite disturbance. Proves Proposition 7.7

example.name: ETCS Train Disturbance [reactivity]
example.description: Proves safety of the ETCS train control protocol case study despite disturbance in the physical dynamics. This example proves that the train can react to situation changes. Proves Proposition 7.8

example.name: ETCS Train Disturbance [safety]
example.description: Proves safety of the ETCS train control protocol case study despite disturbance in the physical dynamics. This example proves that a train never leaves its movement authority (MA=m) and, thus, cannot crash into other trains. Proves Proposition 7.9

example.name: Aircraft Roundabout [simple]
example.description: Essentials of the tangential roundabout maneuver (TRM) for collision avoidance in air traffic control. This example proves that TRM always separates aircraft by at least the protected zone. Please note, that this is the simplest possible version of the safety requirement for the TRM. The verification of the TRM system itself requires a much more advanced model. Proves Theorem 3.4

example.name: Aircraft Roundabout 3 [simple]
example.description: Essentials of the tangential roundabout maneuver (TRM) for collision avoidance in air traffic control with 3 aircraft. This example proves that TRM always separates aircraft by at least the protected zone. Please note, that this is the simplest possible version of the safety requirement for the TRM. The verification of the TRM system itself requires a much more advanced model. Proves Section 8.2.4

example.name: Aircraft Roundabout 4 [simple]
example.description: Essentials of the tangential roundabout maneuver (TRM) for collision avoidance in air traffic control with 4 aircraft. This example proves that TRM always separates aircraft by at least the protected zone. Please note, that this is the simplest possible version of the safety requirement for the TRM. The verification of the TRM system itself requires a much more advanced model. Proves Figure 8.9

example.name: Aircraft Bounded Speed Choice
example.description: Shows that the control parameters for the aircraft can be chosen such that resulting speed vectors are in a bounded range meeting external speed requirements of the aircraft. Proves equation (3.14)

example.name: Aircraft Bounded Maneuver Speed
example.description: Shows that the speed v of the aircraft is maintained even when it changes its angular velocity om nondeterministically during the flight (free flight). Proves Example 3.16

example.name: Aircraft Flyable Roundabout Entry
example.description: Shows that the safe tangential configuration is reached by a flyable curve. Proves equation (8.3)

example.name: Aircraft Flyable Entry Feasible
example.description: Shows that the safe tangential configuration is feasible. Proves equation (8.4)

example.name: Aircraft Flyable Entry Circular
example.description: Shows that the flyable entry is circular. Proves equation (8.6)

example.name: Aircraft Limited Progress
example.description: Shows that, regardless of the angular velocities, the aircraft only make limited progress in bounded time when starting with bounded speeds. Proves equation (8.9)

example.name: Aircraft Negotiation Feasible
example.description: Shows that there always is a choice of center, radius, and common angular velocity which is feasible. Proves equation (8.17)

example.name: Aircraft Negotiation Success
example.description: Shows that the negotiation is successful. Proves equation (8.18)

example.name: Aircraft Mutual Negotiation Success
example.description: Shows that the mutual negotiation is successful. Proves equation (8.19)

example.name: Aircraft Mutual Negotiation Feasible
example.description: Shows that the mutual negotiation is feasible. Proves equation (8.21)

example.name: Aircraft Simultaneous Exit Separation
example.description: Shows that the aircraft stay safely separated during the exit maneuver. Proves equation (8.27)

example.name: Aircraft Different Exit Direction
example.description: Shows that the aircraft will exit in different directions during the exit maneuver. Proves equation (8.29)

example.name: Bouncing Ball [simple]
example.description: A fully parametric version of the bouncing ball that jumps up and down but is bounced back from the ground. This version has a fixed bouncing constant c. Proves Figure 2.20

example.name: Bouncing Ball [dynamic]
example.description: A fully parametric version of the bouncing ball that jumps up and down but is bounced back from the ground. This version has a bouncing coefficient c that can changer over time by a nondeterministic assignment c:=*

example.name: Bouncing Ball [aerodynamic]
example.description: A fully parametric version of the aerodynamic bouncing ball that jumps up and down but is bounced back from the ground. This version follows aerodynamic principles of wind resistance.

example.name: Simple Acceleration
example.description: Simple example of an accelerating point. It is provable with Grobner Basis backend.

example.name: Magnetic Field
example.description: Magnetic field example. It is provable with Grobner Basis backend.

example.name: Controlled Moving Point
example.description: Simple example of a controlled moving point that moves towards zero.

example.name: Water Tank
example.description: Standard water tank model, which regulates water level y between 1 and 12 by filling or emptying the water tank. Changing valves has a delayed effect in this example. Proves Example C.1

example.name: Damped Oscillator
example.description: Damped oscillator. Proves Example 3.21

example.name: Switched Damped Oscillator
example.description: Switched damped oscillator switching between two modes of damped oscillators at some diagonals. Identifies the assumptions on the switching surface taht are required for safety. Proof hints: The automatic proof pauses at some point. Then use diffweaken and resume automatic proof. Proves Figure 3.19
